Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Parsing Metalanguage and the Use-Mention Distinction

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to developed methods for computers to detect where in written language people describe words and phrases, and to identify particular words or phrases being described. People frequently use metalanguage--that is, statements about language--to introduce new words, discuss spelling or pronunciation, clarify meaning, and correct mistakes. Previously the clues in English vocabulary and grammar that identify metalanguage were unknown, and this research was the first effort to begin finding them. In the future, the methods developed by this project will make it easier to interact with computers in the same natural language that people use when interacting with each other.

To study metalanguage, many samples of the phenomenon were gathered from existing language resources (called corpora) and then examined for recurring patterns. Using those patterns, computer algorithms called classifiers were trained to automatically detect metalanguage in text. A small set of clues in vocabulary and grammar were found to be very common and accurate as predictors of metalanguage. Further research on this topic will make it possible for computers to parse and “understand” the information conveyed by metalanguage, leading to improvements in technologies such as conversational computer interfaces, language tutoring systems, and automated dictionary building tools.
